Department of Chemistry, School of Science, King Mongkut’s Institute of Technology Ladkrabang Chalongkrung Road, Ladkrabang Bangkok 10520 Thailand Copper phyllosilicate (CuPS) was used as a bifunctional catalyst for hydrodeoxygenation of methyl palmitate (MP) to produce long-chain α-olefins without the loss of carbon backbone. The CuPS catalysts were prepared by ammonia evaporation-hydrothermal method. The crystal structure, surface area, reducibility, Cu dispersion, Cu particle size and acidity of the catalysts were examined by XRD, BET, H2-TPR, TEM, NH3-TPD and Py-IR. The existence of Cu2+ species (octahedral (O h )/square planar (Sq)), Cu+ and Cu0 upon calcination/reduction was investigated by in situ TR-XANES. The Cu dispersion was related to the Cu+ fraction in CuPS, while Brønsted acid sites (BAS) depends on Cu0 particles. The MP conversion to 1-hexadecene proceeds via hydrogenation-dehydration promoted by the synergy of Cu0 surface and Brønsted acid sites at the interface. The α-olefin selectivity depends on a balance between Cu+ and Cu loading. The 20CuPS possessing 10% Cu+ fraction, provides a high conversion of 72% with 45% α-olefin selectivity. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Copper phyllosilicate Methyl palmitate Linear long-chain α-olefins Bifunctional catalyst 1 Introduction Linear long-chain α-olefins are necessary intermediate chemicals widely used as detergents, surfactants, plasticizers, synthetic lubricants, synthetic drilling fluids and co-monomers [1–3]. Industrially, they are produced by the oligomerization of ethylene, which is derived from non-renewable feedstock [4]. Alternatively, fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs), obtained from bio-based resources, offer an renewable route to produce these linear long-chain α-olefins [5–7]. Due to a ample supply of palm oils, especially in South East Asia, South America and Africa, and the available technology to commercially produce FAMEs from palm oils, these bring out the opportunity to use FAMEs as a feedstock to produce linear long-chain α-olefins [8–10]. Typically, the hydrodeoxygenation of FAMEs to α-olefins could proceed via decarbonylation [11] and hydrogenation-dehydration [12]. The decarbonylation yields long-chain α-olefins from the removal of the ester as CO and H2, over various metal catalysts, such as (Pd [13], Pt [14]) Ni [15] and Co [16,17]. However, this process suffers two-carbon loss (the methyl and the carbonyl groups), bearing α-olefins with one carbon shorter than the parent FAMEs backbone. Furthermore, with the ready hydrogen dissociation ability of these metal catalysts, the olefin formed can be subsequently hydrogenated to paraffin. Hydrogenation-dehydration, on the other hand, could provide the α-olefins without the carbon loss over bifunctional catalysts. In this reaction, FAMEs would be selectively hydrogenated at CO to alcohol (C-OH) intermediate that could be subsequently dehydrated to α-olefins. The methanol formed in the first step (hydrogenation) can then be recycled for the FAMEs production from triglyceride [18]. A preferred bifunctional catalyst for hydrogenation-dehydration shall consist of a chemoselective metal for CO hydrogenation and a weak acid for alcohol dehydration. Typically, Cu-based catalysts interact with FAMEs via η1 adsorption of CO, providing selective hydrogenation of ester to alcohol without the decarbonylation [19,20]. Pestman, et al. suggested that the selective CO hydrogenation can be obtained from the synergistic effect of Cu+/Cu0 species in the partially reduced CuO catalysts, where Cu+ species is responsible for η1 adsorption of CO and Cu0 species is active for CO hydrogenation [21]. Other studies also show that the hydrogenation of carboxylic acids yields mainly alcohols over Cu-based catalysts [22–24]. The presence of Cu+ in these catalysts also provides weak acid sites for the subsequent dehydration of the alcohol produced. However, maintaining both Cu+ and Cu0 species in the catalysts with high Cu dispersion is challenging because of the poor interaction between Cu and the support. Furthermore, the Cu agglomerate and/or sintering would be readily at above 10 wt% Cu loading [25,26]. Recently, the copper catalyst derived from copper phyllosilicate (CuPS) precursor has been reported to possess a high Cu dispersion (even at >20 wt% Cu loading) with the presence of both Cu+ and Cu0 species after the reduction. This is due to a strong interaction between Cu2+ and SiO2 in the well-defined lamellar structure [27]. Gong, et al. mentioned that such high dispersion in CuPS is because of the presence of Cu+ species [28]. Jiang, et al. also commented on the presence of Cu+/Cu0 in CuPS for hydrogenation of adipic acid to 1,6-hexanediol [29]. Apart from weak acid sites provided by Cu+ species, the chrysocolla structure of CuPS could offer additional Brønsted acid sites from surface silanol groups [30]. Che, et al. mentioned that the condensation of Si-O-Ni-OH species in the octahedral layer of phyllosilicate structure during the calcination yielded NiOx clusters and Si-OH [31]. Such generated silanols, especially those on the perimeter of metal particles, could have a stronger Brønsted acidity than that of the typical silanol. Even though no catalytic activity of these Brønsted acid sites has been revealed, these sites shall promote the dehydration of alcohols to α-olefins over the CuPS. Moreover, the high selectivity of α-olefins could be obtained since Cu is less active towards the olefin hydrogenation. With this regard, we reported the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of FAMEs to produce linear long-chain α-olefins using CuPS catalysts in a gas-phase reactor under atmospheric H2 pressure. Methyl palmitate (MP) was selected as a feed model for FAMEs. The effect of Cu loading on the reducibility and Cu dispersion was evaluated by the dissociative N2O adsorption followed by a subsequent H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) test, and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The existence and transformation of Cu species in the CuPS upon calcination and reduction were investigated using in situ time-resolved X-ray adsorption near-edge structure spectroscopy (in-situ TR-XANES) and X-ray diffraction spectroscopy (XRD). The influence of Cu loading on the nature of Cu species and its relationships with Brønsted/Lewis acid sites were investigated. The structure-activity relation of active Cu surface area, acid sites, and the selectivity of linear long-chain α-olefin was thereby revealed. 2 Experimental procedure Copper phyllosilicates (CuPS) were prepared by the ammonia evaporation hydrothermal method [32]. Briefly, the appropriate amounts of Cu(NO3)2•3 H2O were dissolved in 30 mL of deionized water. Then, four equivalent moles of NH3 (30 wt% NH4OH solution) were added to the solution under vigorous stirring. After 30 min, 5.84 g of colloidal silica (LUDOX® AS-40, Sigma-Aldrich 420840) were introduced into this mixture and stirred for 24 h. The mixture was then heated at 80 °C in a water bath to evaporate NH3, in which the pH was dropped from 11 to ~7. The remaining mixture was transferred to Teflon-line autoclaved and was then treated hydrothermally at 150 ๐C for 24 h. After that, the suspension was filtered, washed with deionized water, and dried at 60 °C for 24 h. The obtained solids were then calcined in a horizontal tube furnace under air (60 mL/min) at 400 °C (2 °C/min) for 4 h. The samples were denoted as xCuPS where x = 8, 20 and 30 wt% of Cu loading. These samples were reduced at 250 °C (10 °C/min) under H2 (60 mL/min) for 2 h. 20 wt% copper supported on silica (denoted as 20Cu/SiO2) was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method using copper nitrate trihydrate as a precursor. Briefly, 9.51 g of Cu(NO3)2•3 H2O were dissolved in 30.0 mL of deionized water. After that, 10 g of SiO2 (Davisil Grade 646, Supelco 236845) were impregnated by the prepared solution to the wetness and was dried at 50 °C. The process was repeated until the prepared solution was used up. Then, the obtained solid was dried in an oven at 70 °C for 24 h. The dried sample was calcined in a horizontal tube furnace under air (60 mL/min) at 400 °C (10 °C/min) for 4 h. The obtained samples were reduced at 250 °C (10 °C/min) under H2 (60 mL/min) for 2 h, assigned as 20Cu/SiO2. The amounts of Cu loading in the catalysts were determined by X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF, Bruker s8 tiger). The crystal structure of the samples was examined by X-ray diffractometer (XRD) using D8-Discover diffractometer with CuKα radiation. Nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured at − 195 °C after dehydration under vacuum at 150 °C for 12 h on a Quantachrome gas analyzer. The Cu nanoparticle size was measured by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on a JEM-2010. The sample was dispersed in ethanol and deposited on copper grids coated with transparent carbon foil and dried in vacuum. The reducibility of all samples was evaluated by the self-designed H2-TPR system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (VICI). Briefly, before the reduction, 15 mg of catalyst was calcined in air at 400 °C (10 °C/min) for 2 h and cooldown under N2. The catalyst was then reduced under 10%H2/Ar from 50 to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The copper dispersion was estimated by dissociative N2O adsorption technique. Briefly, after the first H2-TPR at 250 °C for 2 h, the sample was subsequently treated in a pure N2O stream at 60 °C for 1 h. After that the N2O was flushed with N2 at 60 °C for 30 min and then raised to 110 °C and hold for 30 min. Finally, the second H2-TPR was then performed from room temperature to 250 °C, to quantify the surface Cu species. The copper dispersion (D Cu ) can be estimated by fraction of surface Cu (2nd H2-TPR) over total Cu (1st H2-TPR). The copper dispersion and specific copper surface area can be calculated, as described by Sagar, et al [33]. The acidity of samples was quantified by NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) using 1% NH3/Ar, equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. Briefly, prior to the NH3 adsorption, 50 mg of catalysts were calcined in air at 400 °C (10 °C/min) for 2 h and cooldown under N2. After that, the sample was adsorbed by 1% NH3/Ar at room temperature for 1 h. Then, the remaining 1% NH3/Ar was flushed by He for 1 h. Finally, the NH3 desorption was performed from 50 to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were analyzed using pyridine-adsorbed infrared spectroscopy (Py-IR, Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 spectrometer with an in-situ quartz cell). Briefly, the sample was reduced at 250 °C for 2 h under 10% H2/Ar (50 mL/min). Once it was cooled down to 150 °C, the sample was purged by pyridine vapor for 1 h. After that, excess pyridine was removed under a vacuum (1.2 × 10–3 Pa) for 1 h. Finally, the sample was heated to 200 °C (10 °C/min) and the FTIR spectra were recorded [30]. In situ time-resolved X-ray adsorption near-edge structure (in situ TR-XANES) experiments were performed at BL2.2: TRXAS, Synchrotron Light Research Institute (SLRI), Thailand. An energy dispersive monochromator and position sensitive detector was employed to perform XANES measurement [34]. The Cu K-edge XANES was collected using the integration time of 2000 ms with an average of 10 scans. The oxidation state of copper composition was estimated by Linear Combination Fitting (LCF) of XANES spectra over Athena software using Cu foil, Cu2O, CuO and CuSO4 as a standard. The methyl palmitate conversion was investigated in a continuous fixed-bed reactor made with a glass tube (8 mm O.D.) under the atmospheric pressure of H2. Before the catalytic testing, the catalyst (250 mg) was calcined under air (60 mL/min) at 400 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min for 2 h. It was then naturally cooled down to 50°C under N2. Next, the catalyst was reduced under H2 (60 mL/min) at 250 °C (10 °C/min) for 2 h. Finally, the reaction was performed using 10 wt% methyl palmitate in dodecane (2.4 mL/h) under the stream of H2 (180 mL/min). The liquid products were trapped with iso-propanol and collected to analyze by gas chromatography (7890B, Agilent, USA) equipped with a capillary column (MXT-1, 60 m, ID 0.25 mm) and flame ionization detector (FID). The analysis was started by ramping the oven from 50 to 280 °C (12 °C/min) and hold at the final temperature for 5 min. Nitrogen was used as carrier gas with a linear velocity of 30 cm/sec. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization Cu contents of the prepared catalysts are summarized in Table 1. The observed metal loadings are in agreement with the desired catalyst preparation. All calcined CuPS samples show weak XRD peaks at 30.8˚, 35.0˚, 57.5˚ and 62.4˚, corresponding to the chrysocolla characteristics (Cu2Si2O5(OH)2) of the copper phyllosilicate [27], as shown in Fig. 1a, ii-iv. The characteristic peak of copper phyllosilicate was more pronounced when copper loading was increased, particularly at ≥ 20 wt%Cu. This is because the formation of the chrysocolla structure requires Cu2+ in the octahedral layers [32]. In a supportive manner, a board signal of amorphous SiO2 at 2θ 20˚–30˚ become flatter, especially in 30CuPS [29]. The surface area of the samples is also increased upon the increment of copper content (152–400 m2/g for 8–30 wt%CuPS), as in Table 1 entry 1–3. furthermore, all samples show a type IV N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm (Fig. S1), indicating the mesoporous character of phyllosilicates with the pore diameters in the range of 3–50 nm, similar to those reported in the literature [29]. It is important to mention that the CuO phase was not detected in all calcined CuPS samples, even at 30 wt% loading. However, the characteristic peaks of CuO were clearly pronounced in 20Cu/SiO2 with the crystalline size of 26 nm, as shown in Fig. 1a, i. These observations lead to the suggestion that the Cu2+ species is highly dispersed as well-defined Cu2+ ions strongly interact with the SiO2 layers in octahedral sites in the chrysocolla structure of the phyllosilicates [35]. On the other hand, a much weaker interaction between Cu2+ and SiO2 could lead to an agglomeration of CuO particles upon calcination for the impregnated sample. This also results in a notable drop in surface area (from 331 to198 m2/g) compared with the parent SiO2 support, presumably due to the pore blocking (from 1.33 to 1.03 cm3/g). It is worth noting that the observed mesopores in 20Cu/SiO2 belong to the silica support (Davisil). To gain more details about the Cu species in the calcined CuPS samples, the in situ time-resolved X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (in situ TR-XANES) was performed, as shown in Fig. 2. The Cu edges energy for Cu foil, Cu2O, CuO (square planar geometry, Cu2+(Sq)) and CuSO4 (octahedral geometry, Cu2+(O h )), are 8979.1, 8980.5, 8990.2 and 8992.3 eV, respectively (Table S1). Compared to the Cu standards, all calcined CuPS samples exhibit characteristic edge energy absorption for Cu2+ at ~8991 eV. It is important to emphasize that the values fall between the Cu edge energy of CuSO4 (8992.3 eV) and CuO (8890.2 eV). Hence, it is likely that a mixture of octahedral Cu2+(O h ) and square planar Cu2+(Sq) is present in the calcined CuPS samples. However, the line-shape spectra of the samples are more resemble that of CuSO4, without a pre-edge feature at ~8984 eV that represents the square planer Cu2+(Sq) species (Fig. 2b). This indicates that the majority of the Cu2+ species in the CuPS samples exist in the octahedral geometry, presumably within the chrysocolla structure. To quantify the octahedral Cu2+(O h ) and square planar Cu2+(Sq) species, the linear combination fitting (LCF) of in situ TR-XANES spectra was performed on the calcined samples, as examples shown in Fig. S2. The composition from the LCF as a function of temperature is shown in Fig. 3. At 50°C, the 8CuPS possesses relatively higher fraction of octahedral Cu2+(O h ) (76%), as compared to 20CuPS (66%) and 30CuPS (62%). In consistence with this finding, the Cu edge energy slightly shifts to a lower value for the samples with higher Cu loadings. This could suggest a relatively lower electron density of Cu2+ in 8CuPS, as compared to 20CuPS and 30CuPS. The in situ TR-XANES also demonstrated that the Cu2+(O h ) species are converted into Cu2+(Sq) species, upon heating from 50 °C to 400 °C (Fig. 3, a–c). This is presumably due to (i) the dehydration of adsorbed water at the layer edge and (ii) the dehydroxylation of the interlayered Si-O-Cu-(OH)2, as reported by Heller-Kallai et al. [36]. The dehydroxylation could proceed via protonation of the adjacent hydroxyls, forming a highly dispersed Cu2+(Sq) species, as shown in Scheme 1 . On the contrary, Cu edge energy of calcined 20Cu/SiO2 (8990.2 eV) exactly matches that of the CuO standard (8990.2 eV). Together with a pre-edge feature at ~8984 eV (Fig. 2b), the Cu2+ species in the impregnated sample would virtually exist in 4-coordinate square planar geometry [37]. In line with this view, the LCF shows only Cu2+(Sq) species in 20Cu/SiO2 (Fig. 3d). This result is also consistent with the XRD results where the high crystalline CuO particles are observed. Accordingly, the 20Cu/SiO2 exhibits a relatively broad reduction peak (~220 °C) for large and ununiform CuO particles ( Fig. 4a, i) [32]. While CuPS samples show a sharp reduction peak at lower temperatures (~181–186 °C, Fig. 4a, ii-iv). Together with an absence of CuO peak in the XRD, these features indicate a highly dispersed Cu2+ species in CuPS samples. Moreover, the reduction peak of CuPS samples was decreased from 186 °C (8CuPS) to181 °C (30CuPS). In consistent with in situ TR-XANES, the higher fraction of Cu2+(O h ) species could provide a higher Cu edge energy. This is because the higher number of Cu-O bonding in an octahedral environment, results in an electron deficiency of the Cu2+. Therefore, the Cu2+(O h ) species would interact strongly with the SiO2 layer, leading to a relatively higher reduction temperature, especially for 8CuPS. It is worth noting that Cu content calculated from the H2 consumption of all CuPS samples is less than those determined by the XRF (Table 1), while XRF and H2-TPR estimated Cu contents for 20Cu/SiO2 were nearly identical (18.5 and 18.6 wt%). This suggests that Cu2+ species in CuPS samples might not be fully reduced to metallic Cu, especially at the low Cu loading. As seen in Table S2, approximately 26%, 8% and 4% lower Cu content were observed for 8CuPS, 20CuPS and 30CuPS, respectively. This is in line with a report by Jiang, et al. that Cu+ species were observed in the CuPS, even after the samples were reduced at 300 °C [29]. The presence of Cu+ species could attribute to the strong interaction between Cun+ and SiO2 in the phyllosilicate structure, as discussed earlier. Since 8CuPS shows a notable loss of H2 consumption (Table S2) and relatively higher reduction temperature (Fig. 4a, ii), this sample presumably contains a higher fraction of Cu+ after the reduction. To investigate the nature of Cu species under the reduction condition, the in-situ TR-XANES under 10%H2/N2 was consecutively performed after heating at 400 °C for 2 h, as shown in Fig. 5. From 50–210 °C, a further decrease in Cu2+(O h ) species in all CuPS samples was observed, despite that the fraction of this species remains constant under heating in air at 400 °C (Fig. 3). In response to such decrease, Cu2+(Sq) species gradually increased, suggesting that the dehydroxylation of Cu2+(O h ) species to Cu2+(Sq) species was promoted under hydrogen. It is possible that the hydrogen could reversibly dissociate Si-O-Cu-O-Si forming internal Si-OH and H-Cu-O-Si. The latter species may also react with the adjacent HO-Cu-O-Si, liberating H2 and Cu-O-Cu [38]. As H2 is equally consumed and released in this process, no change in the TPR signal was observed. Nevertheless, in situ TR-XANES experiment has suggested that the coordination of Cu2+ has been modified under hydrogen without change in the oxidation state. The reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+ species could be initially observed at 220 °C, followed by the formation of Cu0 at 230 °C (Fig. 5, a–c). These two species were evolved along with the decreases in Cu2+(O h ) and Cu2+(Sq) species. While the Cu2+(Sq) was retained in high proportion, the increase in Cu+ appears to correspond with the decrease in Cu2+(O h ). Above 210 °C, the decrease in Cu2+(Sq) and the increase in Cu0 species were significant, showing similar rates of phase transformation. This observation suggests that the Cu2+(O h ) species would be partially reduced to Cu+ at below 210°C, presumably due to a strong interaction of Cu+ in octahedral geometry with the SiO2 layers. Nevertheless, some of Cu+ could be further reduced to Cu0, as observed by a decrease in Cu+ fraction at > 225°C. On the other hand, the Cu+ is less stabilized in the square planar geometry, leading to a complete reduction of the Cu2+(Sq) species to Cu0. In comparison, the impregnated sample (20Cu/SiO2), that contained only Cu2+(Sq) species, was fully reduced to Cu0, without Cu+ intermediate species during H2 reduction (Fig. 5, d). Accordingly, the samples possessing a higher fraction of Cu2+(O h ) species (i.e., 8CuPS) would provide a higher Cu+ composition. After holding at 250 °C for 2 h under 10%H2/N2, the Cu+ fraction retained in the samples are in order of 16.2%(8CuPS) > 10.1%(20CuPS) > 7.6%(30CuPS). This trend is consistent with the increase in H2 consumption of respective samples, as discussed in H2-TPR. Although H2-TPR and in situ TR-XANES suggest that CuPS can be readily reduced to Cu metal, no diffraction peak for Cu0 (2θ = 43.2 ˚, 50.4 ˚ and 74.2 ˚) was observed in the XRD pattern of the reduced samples (Fig. 1b, ii-iv). This suggests that very fine Cu0 particles could be formed in the reduced CuPS. In line with this view, TEM shows average Cu particle sizes of the CuPS samples in the range of 1.9–4.9 nm ( Fig. 6, a-c), much smaller than that of Cu/SiO2 (~11 nm, Fig. 6, d). Since the lamellar structure of CuPS could be partially collapsed upon reduction, a notable decrease in surface area of all CuPS samples was observed (Table 1). Nevertheless, the remaining lamellar structure of reduced catalysts (as observed by TEM, Fig. S3) would retain Cu+ species, as discussed earlier. Such Cu+/SiO2 layers may strongly interact with the metallic Cu particles, preventing agglomeration of the Cu0 particles [35,39]. Accordingly, high dispersion of Cu particle can be obtained for all CuPS samples (~60–80%), depending on Cu+ fraction in the samples, as shown in Figs. 4b and 5. Therefore, an increase in Cu loadings (from 8% to 30%) i.e., a decrease in Cu+ fraction, leads to a proportional increase in Cu particle size (from 1.9 to 4.9 nm) i.e., a decrease in Cu dispersion (from ~80–60%), as shown in Fig. S4. On the other hand, the large Cu0 particles of 20Cu/SiO2 could attribute to the low interaction of the bulk CuO with the silica support. This leads to a complete reduction of Cu2+(Sq) species to Cu0 without Cu+ species, as observed in Fig. 5d. Hence, the metallic Cu could be readily agglomerated on 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst after the reduction, resulting in a low Cu dispersion (~10%, Table 1, Fig. 4b, iv). The acid sites of all Cu-based catalysts were investigated by the NH3-TPD, as shown in Fig. 7a. The desorption peaks were deconvoluted into three peaks by the Gaussian deconvolution method. All Cu-based catalysts contain three desorption peaks. The peaks at 120 °C was referred to weak acid sites derived from surface silanol [40], whereas a broad peak at 250 °C could be attributed to the NH3 adsorbed on the internal silanol within the micropores or interlayers [41]. In addition, the peak at 160 °C can be referred to medium acid sites derived from the Cu species [42]. The acidity, calibrated with standard 1% NH3 in He, for each peak is listed in Table 2. It can be seen that medium acid sites of CuPS increased with the Cu loading, from 9 µmol/g (8CuPS) to 16 µmol/g (30CuPS), while sites derived from the silanol groups (Si-OH) was similar. Moreover, the 20Cu/SiO2 showed a much lower medium acid site (5 µmol/g) than the phyllosilicate counterpart (20CuPS, 12 µmol/g). This could attribute to the lower Cu surface area of the impregnated samples, as discussed earlier. To gain more details of the specific acid sites over the reduced catalysts, the Py-IR was performed. As seen in Fig. 7b, the CuPS catalysts show adsorption bands at 1450 and 1606 cm-1, attributed to the pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acid sites (LAS) [43], and the bands at 1530 and 1633 cm-1, evidenced for pyridine bonded with Brønsted acid sites (BAS) [44]. The band at 1490 cm -1, for both BAS and LAS [45] was also observed. The acidity of the samples was calibrated with the HZSM-5 standard (Si/Al ~ 21) with known acidity and listed in Table 2. Unlike CuPS catalysts, 20Cu/SiO2 exhibit only an adsorption band at 1580 cm-1 that could refer to the adsorbed pyridine on the silanol group (Si-OH). The Lewis acid sites (LAS) in CuPS samples could be derived from the remaining Cu+ species, as evidenced by in situ TR-XANES. In support with this view, the LAS was increased linearly with the remaining Cu+ content in the samples, as shown in Fig. 8a. However, the amount of LAS is lower than the overall Cu+ content (LAS/Cu+ <1, Table 2) indicating that only some Cu+ species were exposed to the surface. The rest would remain within the layered structure. The Cu+ species was not present in 20Cu/SiO2 after the reduction, and therefore the LAS adsorption band was barely detected on the impregnated catalyst. The number of BAS was increased with the Cu loading, especially the Cu0 content, as shown in Fig. 8b. The relatively lower BAS, as compared to the Cu content, suggesting that BAS could be derived from the silanol (Si-OH) group at the interface of Cu particles [46]. The perturbation of d-band electrons of Cu metal on the interface Si-OH results in an electron deficiency of hydrogen at the perimeter [42]. Hence, 30CuPS that possesses a higher metallic Cu phase (see Fig. 5) would exhibit a higher number of BAS. However, the number of BAS at the perimeter would also depend on the Cu metal particle size. The smaller the particle size, the higher the number of BAS at the perimeter. In other words, the sample with high Cu dispersion would possess a higher BAS at the perimeter. Accordingly, a higher ratio of BAS/Cu on the surface (Cu s 0) was obtained for 8CuPS with a higher Cu metal dispersion (Table 2). 3.2 Catalytic activity The gas-phase hydrodeoxygenation of methyl palmitate (MP) was performed at 250 °C under atmospheric H2 pressure. The 20CuPS catalyst shows ~5 folds conversion higher than 20Cu/SiO2 catalyst (73% vs. 13%), as shown in Table 3, entry 1 and 2. Such high activity of the 20CuPS catalyst could mainly derive from a higher Cu dispersion (73%), as compared with that of 20Cu/SiO2 (10%). In other words, the 20CuPS possesses an active Cu surface area (92.3 m2/g), higher than that of 20Cu/SiO2 (12.7 m2/g, Table 1). This could attribute to the existent of well-defined Cu2+ species (Cu2+(O h ), Cu2+(Sq)) in 20CuPS structure, as discussed by in situ TR-XANES. These Cu2+ species could be reduced to Cu0 and Cu+ species, and the latter could inhibit the agglomeration of metallic Cu particles after the reduction, resulting in very fine metallic Cu particles, as observed in Fig. 6b. The products from 20CuPS and 20Cu/SiO2 catalysts include hexadecanal, hexadecanol, haxadecene and hexadecane. Among the C16-olefins, 1-hexadecene is mainly obtained, together with a trace amount of inner- and iso-olefins. However, trace amounts of pentadecene and pentadecane, C15-products could be observed for 20Cu/SiO2, presumably via decarbonylation of methyl palmitate. None of these products can be detected over CuPS catalysts even at a higher conversion. This could emphasize the ability of the Cu-based catalyst to suppress decarbonylation reactions, which are typically enhanced by oxophillic metals (Co, Ni, and Fe [15–17]) and noble metal catalysts (Pd and Pt [13,14]). To verify the evolution of these products, the correlation of conversion and product yields with the contact time was investigated for 20CuPS, as shown in Fig. 9. At the initial (< 94 g·h/mol), small amounts of methanol could be observed along with the increase in methyl palmitate conversion. It is worth noting that most of the methanol produced was in the gas phase and cannot be efficiently trapped during analysis. The observed increase in methanol with the conversion suggests that the hydrogenolysis at the C-O bond of the palmitate ester was primarily promoted, presumably via the adsorbed CO η1 species on the Cu surface [10]. In support with the C-O hydrogenolysis, neither methane nor palmitic acid was observed. Instead, hexadecanal and hexadecanol were primarily obtained. The lower yield of hexadecanal, as compared to hexadecanol, could suggest that the hexadecanal would be an intermediate, consecutively hydrogenated to hexadecanol. Hexadecene and hexadecane significantly increase with the conversion while hexadecanal and hexadecanol remain leveled. This suggests that the primarily produced hexadecanol may undergo dehydration to form 1-hexadecene. The dehydration activity of these CuPS catalysts could be related to their acid sites, as discussed earlier. One could expect that 1-hexadecene can be further hydrogenated to hexadecane as shown in Fig. S5a. Alternatively, the hexadecane could also be produced in parallel with 1-hexadecene, as seen by a coherent increase in their selectivity ( Fig. 10). This is because the acidity also promotes so-called “hydro-dehydration” of the protonated hexadecanol to hexadecane [12]. At a high conversion (73.2%), 1-hexadecene and hexadecane were major products. In a supportive manner, only 1-hexadecene and hexadecane were obtained once using hexadecanol as a feed shown in Fig. S5b. Therefore, this could suggest that hydrodeoxygenation of methyl palmitate over CuPS catalysts is a series reaction that yields primarily hexadecanal, and then to hexadecanol. The hexadecanol is dehydrated to 1-hexadecene that can be further hydrogenated to hexadecane. In parallel, the hexadecanol can also be hydro-dehydrated to hexadecane. The reaction pathway can be proposed as shown in Scheme 2. As the Cu content increased from 8 wt to 30 wt%, the conversion proportionally increased from ~20–77% (Table 3, entry 2–4). The catalytic activity corresponds with the active Cu surface area, as shown in Fig. 11a. This is also the case for 20Cu/SiO2, suggesting that hydrogen dissociation on the Cu surface is a rate-determining step for this reaction [35]. At relatively low temperature (~250°C), adsorption of methyl palmitate, a polar molecule with high MW, would be readily facilitated, especially at the interface. Dissociation of H2 and hydrogen spillover to the adsorbed methyl palmitate could be promoted, especially by the catalyst with a high Cu surface area, i.e., 30CuPS. In addition, 1-hexadecene and hexadecane selectivity proportionally increase with Cu loading, as seen from Table 3, entry 2–4. Meanwhile, the hexadecanol selectivity was sharply decreased. This indicates that the dehydration and hydro-dehydration of hexadecanol are readily promoted at higher Cu loading, especially at 30 wt%. This is clearly due to the increase in Brønsted acidity of CuPS catalysts, as seen in an opposite trend for hexadecanol selectivity (Fig. 11b). As BAS at the perimeter is increased, the primarily produced hexadecanol would be readily protonated and dehydrated or hydro-dehydrated to hydrocarbons, as discussed previously. Nevertheless, when the Cu loading increased from 20 wt% to 30 wt%, the hexadecene selectivity was leveled off. While the hexadecane selectivity was steadily promoted over 30CuPS. This could attribute to the higher Cu surface area on 30CuPS catalyst leading to the higher hydro-dehydration ability. It is worth noting that the Lewis acidic Cu+ species do not particularly play a role in alcohol dehydration. This is deduced from higher hydrocarbon selectivity over 30CuPS (~77%), as compared to that over 20CuPS (~66%), despite a similar Cu+ content (~0.33-0.34 mmol/g, Table S2) and Lewis acidity (~4.1–4.3 mmol/g, Table 2). Hence, it is suggested that only the BAS in CuPS catalyst promotes the dehydration and hydro-dehydration of hexadecanol to linear long-chain olefins and paraffin, respectively. As the hydrodeoxygenation of methyl palmitate is a series reaction, the product selectivity would depend on the conversion. Accordingly, the products selectivity was better when CuPS catalysts were tested at the same conversion, as shown in Table 3, entry 3, 5, 6. Even at a similar conversion (~20%), low selectivity of hexadecene was still obtained for 8CuPS. This suggests that, in addition to BAS, Cu dispersion seems to play the role for linear long-chain α-olefin selectivity, as seen in Fig. 12. Since the reduced 8CuPS possess small Cu particles (high dispersion) and a high fraction of Cu+ species (Fig. 5), hexadecanol can be readily desorbed from the surface after its formation. This is presumably because Cu+ is much less effective for η1-coordination of alcohol but interacts strongly with the carbonyl group (CO) of the feed [47]. Accordingly, the presence of Cu+ makes the competitive adsorption by the feed more sensitive, particularly on small Cu particles [48]. This combination leads to weaker adsorption of hexadecanol on such complex Cu+-Cu surfaces. Therefore, the dehydration and hydro-dehydration of long-chain alcohol would be less effective on the small Cu particles and a high fraction of Cu+ species. 4 Conclusions Copper phyllosilicate (CuPS) shows high activity for hydrodeoxygenation of methyl palmitate to linear long-chain α-olefin, i.e., 1-hexadecene. No carbon loss due to decarbonylation was observed for all CuPS catalysts. The hydrodeoxygenation activity was related to the active Cu surface area and Brønsted acid sites at the metal-support interface. In situ TR-XANES experiments evidence that the octahedrally coordinated Cu2+(O h ) species in the chrysocolla structure leads to the formation of the partially reduced Cu species (Cu+) that exerts highly dispersed Cu particles after reduction. In addition, the co-existence of Cu+ at the metal/support interface provides Brønsted acid sites in a closed proximity to the Cu metal particle, which promotes the dehydration of hexadecanol, primarily produced by the hydrogenation of methyl palmitate. However, the CuPS with an excessively high Cu+ fraction was less effective in promoting the dehydration of hexadecanol to 1-hexadecene, due to the competitive adsorption of methyl palmitate, against the hexadecanol, on the small Cu particle. Conversely, the catalyst with a low Cu+ fraction provides larger Cu particles that promote hydro-dehydration to undesirable paraffin. The CuPS catalyst with a high number of BAS and a high Cu0 dispersion, i.e., 20CuPS, is considered as the most effective in the hydrodeoxygenation of methyl palmitate to 1-hexadecene. coredata.dc:description: Copper phyllosilicate (CuPS) was used as a bifunctional catalyst for hydrodeoxygenation of methyl palmitate (MP) to produce long-chain α-olefins without the loss of carbon backbone. The CuPS catalysts were prepared by ammonia evaporation-hydrothermal method. The crystal structure, surface area, reducibility, Cu dispersion, Cu particle size and acidity of the catalysts were examined by XRD, BET, H2-TPR, TEM, NH3-TPD and Py-IR. The existence of Cu2+ species (octahedral (O h )/square planar (Sq)), Cu+ and Cu0 upon calcination/reduction was investigated by in situ TR-XANES. The Cu dispersion was related to the Cu+ fraction in CuPS, while Brønsted acid sites (BAS) depends on Cu0 particles. The MP conversion to 1-hexadecene proceeds via hydrogenation-dehydration promoted by the synergy of Cu0 surface and Brønsted acid sites at the interface. The α-olefin selectivity depends on a balance between Cu+ and Cu loading. The 20CuPS possessing 10% Cu+ fraction, provides a high conversion of 72% with 45% α-olefin selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Linear long-chain α-olefins from hydrodeoxygenation of methyl palmitate over copper phyllosilicate catalysts
